contentrichtext.text: {{Other uses|Maroon (disambiguation)}} [[Image:Pyle pirate marooned.jpg|thumb|[[Howard Pyle]]'s 19th-century illustration of a marooned pirate]] [[Image:Marooned (close up).jpg|thumb|Pyle's 20th-century illustration of a marooned pirate]] '''Marooning''' is the intentional leaving of someone in a remote area, such as an uninhabited island. The word first appears in writing in approximately 1709,{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} and is derived from the term [[maroon (people)|maroon]], a word for a fugitive slave, which could be a corruption of [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''cimarrón'', meaning a household animal (or slave) who has run "wild". The practice was a penalty for crewmen, or for captains at the hands of a crew. Generally, a marooned man was set on a deserted island, often no more than a [[shoal|sand bar]] at [[tide|low tide]].<ref>{{Cite book|author=Kraske, Robert|date=2005|title=Marooned: The Strange But True Adventures of Alexander Selkirk|publisher= Clarion Books|isbn=0-618-56843-3}}</ref> He would be given some food, a container of water, and a loaded pistol so he could commit [[suicide]] if he desired.<ref>{{Cite book|author=Hickox, Rex|title=All you wanted to know about 18th century Royal Navy|pages= 121 |publisher=Lulu.com|date=2007|isbn=978-1-4116-3057-4}}</ref> The outcome of marooning was usually fatal, but [[William Greenaway]] and some men loyal to him survived being marooned, as did pirate captain [[Edward England]]. The chief practitioners of marooning were 17th and 18th century [[piracy|pirates]], to such a degree that they were frequently referred to as "marooners." The [[Pirate code|pirate articles]] of captains [[Bartholomew Roberts]] and [[John Phillips (pirate)|John Phillips]] specify marooning as a punishment for cheating one's fellow pirates or other offenses. In this context, to be marooned is euphemistically to be "made governor of an island". During the late 18th century in the American South, "marooning" took on a humorous additional meaning describing an extended camping-out picnic over a period of several days (''Oxford English Dictionary''). The most famous literary reference to marooning probably occurs in [[Robert Louis Stevenson]]'s ''[[Treasure Island]]'' in which [[Ben Gunn (Treasure Island)|Ben Gunn]] is left marooned on the island for three years. Another famous marooning, only partly for punishment, was leaving the sailor [[Alexander Selkirk]] on [[Robinson Crusoe Island|Juan Fernández Island]] off the coast of [[Chile]], in the Pacific Ocean. Selkirk, a sailor with the [[William Dampier|Dampier]] expedition, was worried about the unseaworthy condition of his ship, the ''[[Cinque Ports (1703 ship)|Cinque Ports]]'', and had argued with the captain until he left him ashore on the island where they had briefly stopped for water and food supplies. The ''Cinque Ports'' later sank with the loss of most of her crew. Selkirk was not rescued until four years later, by [[Woodes Rogers]]. Selkirk's travails provided the inspiration for [[Daniel Defoe]]'s novel ''[[Robinson Crusoe]]''. Today, one of the islands on the Chilean coast is named [[Alejandro Selkirk Island]] and another one [[Robinson Crusoe Island]]. ==See also== * [[Castaway]] * [[Walking the plank]] ==References== {{Wiktionary}} {{Reflist}} {{Pirates}} [[Category:Execution methods]] [[Category:Piracy]] [[Category:Mutinies]]
